lessons.title: Filtering
lessons.interactiveContent:
Often, we'll want to filter for items that satisfy a condition, like only students majoring in Biology.

Make sure to pick major = 'Biology'.

lessons.title: All entries
lessons.interactiveContent:
Before filtering student entries, we start by selecting all of them with *.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by *.

lessons.title: Table
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use FROM to specify the name of the table we want to select from, like students.

Make sure to type FROM students.

lessons.title: WHERE
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use WHERE to only select items that fulfill a condition, like having the value Biology on the major column.

Make sure to pick WHERE, followed by major = 'Biology'.

lessons.title: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
The condition we want our items to fulfill comes after the WHERE keyword, like major = 'Biology'.

Make sure to pick major, followed by =, and finally 'Biology'.

lessons.title: Question: Filtering
lessons.interactiveContent:
Why would we need to filter the table items we select?

To get only items that satisfy certain conditionsTo get only items that belong to a specific table

To get only items that satisfy certain conditions.

lessons.title: Question: All entries
lessons.interactiveContent:
What is the first step to filtering items in a table?

We first select the items with SELECTWe just write FILTER at the beginning of the query

We first select the items with SELECT.

lessons.title: Question: WHERE
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which keyword do we use to introduce the condition by which we're filtering?

WHEREFILTER

Make sure to pick WHERE.

lessons.title: Question: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Where do we code the condition when filtering?

After the WHERE keywordAfter the SELECT keyword

After the WHERE keyword.

lessons.title: Example: All entries
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a query that uses * to select all columns of all entries from the membership table.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by * and then FROM, membership, ;.

lessons.title: Example: WHERE
lessons.interactiveContent:
Introduce a condition by coding the WHERE keyword.

Make sure to type WHERE.

lessons.title: Example: Condition
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition so that we only get users with a membership of type pro.

Make sure to pick type = 'pro'.

lessons.title: The `=` operator
lessons.interactiveContent:
We use the = operator to check if two values are equal.

Make sure to type =.

lessons.title: The `=` operator 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Here, we use = to check if the value of an entry in the major column equals Biology.

Make sure to pick major =, followed by 'Biology'.

lessons.title: Text values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Values made up of letters like 'Biology' are text values. In SQL, we write them between simple quotes ' '.

Make sure to pick ', followed by Biology, and finally '.

lessons.title: Number values
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also use = with numeric properties, like selecting only students that have the year value 1.

Make sure to pick year =, followed by 1.

lessons.title: No quotes
lessons.interactiveContent:
Unlike string values, number values like 1 don't need any quotes.

Make sure to type 1.

lessons.title: Question: The `=` operator
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does the = operator do?

It checks if two values are equalIt checks if two values are different

It checks if two values are equal.

lessons.title: Question: The `=` operator 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What are we checking with the = operator in the code below?

For each item, we check if the type property equals 'free'For each item, we check if the 'free' property equals type

For each item, we check if the type property equals 'free'.

lessons.title: Question: Text values
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we write text values in a query?

Between simple quotes ' 'Without any quotes

Between simple quotes ' '.

lessons.title: Question: Number values
lessons.interactiveContent:
How do we write number values in queries?

As they are, without any quotesBetween simple quotes ' ', just like text values

As they are, without any quotes.

lessons.title: Question: No quotes
lessons.interactiveContent:
Which of these is a text value?

'basic'13

Make sure to pick 'basic'.

lessons.title: Example: The `=` operator 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code type followed by = to check if the value on the type column equals 'pro'.

Make sure to type type =.

lessons.title: Example: Text values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Check if the value in the type column equals the text value 'free'.

Make sure to type 'free'.

lessons.title: Example: Number values
lessons.interactiveContent:
Code a condition to filter for users with the numerical property months_active equal to 1.

Make sure to pick months_active, followed by =, and finally 1.

lessons.title: A couple of columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
When using conditions, we don't have to select all columns with *. We can select only a couple, like name and year here.

Make sure to pick SELECT, followed by name, year.

lessons.title: A couple of columns 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
This query gives us the name and year properties of all students that are in their first year.

Make sure to pick name, year, followed by students.

lessons.title: Skip the condition column
lessons.interactiveContent:
We can also skip on selecting the column we put a condition on. Here we select name and major, without year.

Make sure to pick ,, followed by major.

lessons.title: Skip the condition column 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
This query gives us the name and major, but not the year, of all students that are in their first year.

Make sure to pick SELECT name, major, followed by WHERE year = 1.

lessons.title: Question: A couple of columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Do we always need to select all columns when filtering?

No, we can also just select a coupleYes, we always need to select all columns with *

No, we can also just select a couple.

lessons.title: Example: A couple of columns 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What does this query do?

It selects the name and type of each item with the type 'pro'It selects all columns of each item with the type 'pro'

It selects the name and type of each item with the type 'pro'.

lessons.title: Question: Skip the condition column
lessons.interactiveContent:
Do we need to select the column we're putting a condition on when filtering?

No, we don't have to Yes, we always have to select that column

No, we don't have to .

lessons.title: Question: Skip the condition column 2
lessons.interactiveContent:
What's wrong with this query?

There's nothing wrong with the queryIt should also select the column we put a condition on, type

There's nothing wrong with the query.

lessons.title: Example: A couple of columns
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select the email and type properties, for items with a membership type 'pro'.

Make sure to type email, type.

lessons.title: Example: Skip the condition column
lessons.interactiveContent:
Select only email, while setting a condition on the type column, to get the emails of items with a 'free' membership.

Make sure to pick SELECT followed by email and then WHERE, type = 'free'.
